Now as far as the operating margin, yes, 34% is at a low level from what we've had before. That is not – we're not saying we want to stay in it. We're continuing to work through. I mean we're also looking at a period of time where we're going to be investing in the portfolio to make sure that we have strategic investments that we need to make. A lot of that's going to be done through just continuing to be much more efficient in aligning our portfolio as we work through it. And as Gary mentioned before, continue to drive areas of productivity and efficiency continuing on some of the things that we've put in place over the last year to 18 months.

So the overall – if I stand back and look at the overall commitment to what we had talked about last summer or last fall I should say, we kind of looked at a three year model of revenue growth in that 5% to 7% range, profits growing at 7% to 9%. So better than balanced, growing profits faster and with that you're going to have to see some leverage, as Gary talked about. But we'll have to continue to see how that plays out, but that's the objective that we've laid out and one that we use as a management team to make sure as we make the decisions we follow through on it.
Thank you, Paul.
Great. Thanks. Next question.
Thank you. Our next question comes from Simon Leopold, Raymond James.
Hey, Simon.

Hi. Thanks a lot. I'm glad I was able to get a question in. I wanted to follow-up on some of your commentary around data centers and thank you for the clarifications on software defined networking because I think that's caused tons of confusion for folks. But maybe if you could elaborate a little bit to help us with some context and there's really two parts to the one question and legitimately two parts. It's one question.
Okay.

But in terms of data centers, if we could get an understanding of your total revenue derived from data centers. So not just the data center segment but if we could get an understanding of the overall revenue coming from the data center markets including other switching products going in there, routing. I'm believing it's between 10% and 15% of revenue. I want to make sure that that's correct and then just drilling down on the partners, I think there's some concern about the coopetition environment that you addressed. But if we could get an understanding of your diversification or dependency on partners beyond the VCE partnership but how much is coming through partners and direct in that data center vertical in particular. Thank you.

Simon, for the first part, it's almost impossible for us to get that answer. It's not that we shouldn't go through and look at it and maybe, Mel, in future times think about how we'd answer it. If you look at our run rate and what we consider data center and cloud and that's primarily the UCS categories, etcetera, the run rate is well over $1.6 billion type of run rate in terms of that segment. We're up to over I think 22% market share in North America, number two in terms of that segment and rapidly closing in the global market, just a little bit behind the number two player in terms of direction. Our value to our customers has probably never been more relevant in the data center and where we're going to go. And we – Rob laid down a heavy comment. We work across not just an EMC VMware partnership, which is very good and very strong and very successful, but we are an open standard in terms of where we go here, and we fully will control our own destiny not to be dependent on anyone in terms of our long-term strategy, although strategic partnerships must be a part of achieving that strategy.
Your thoughts, Rob?

Well, I think, John, as well you mentioned the Cisco ONE developers approach where we are going to give programmatic access to our operating systems. I think that's going to have a big impact on the value that customers can subscribe through our data center portfolio and it's something that we plan on leveraging going forward. So I think it's an ecosystem play, John, in summary, great relationships across multiple environments and that's exactly what our customers expect.

I've seen this multiple times before also when we look at markets and there's often a lot of excitement, often three to five years before it really is as impactful as some people might think. And each time that has occurred Cisco has not only responded well, we usually lead the transition. We're very comfortable with doing it again, and as I said earlier, this didn't sneak up on us. We've known it's coming for a while and you'll see us address it through strategic partnerships, partnerships where we compete and partner at times. You'll see us address it through internal startups, you'll see us address it through spin-ins and acquisitions. And it's a fun one to play out.

The nice thing is and this is the advantage of not being the big incumbent, is this is largely new greenfields for us to be going into and the direction. And if you think about cloud and you think about virtualization, it is more network centric than anything that's been done. You've got to know the network in this and while there's always a chance we'll be wrong, I think we'll be sitting here three to five years from now and saying it was about the network and the structure.
Next question, please.
Thank you, our next question comes from Brian White with Topeka Capital.
Hi, Brian.

Hi, John. The cloud market 50% growth phenomenal and as we look forward, I'm wondering if there's any other pieces to the puzzle we need to add here, specifically storage, big data and what type of use cases are you seeing the most success in the storage market or in the cloud market? Is it more with enterprise customers or more with carriers?
Okay. Mel's giving me the signal that that's the one we're going to kind of end on in terms of the last question. So we deliver to you all being done by three o'clock as we said we would on it.

In terms of the cloud, the numbers and thank you for the compliment of 50%, it was actually even better, 90% revenue and 58% on the orders. And it does speak to a market where we're just starting to get penetration, and while we have very good share versus the market, the server growth in blade servers is where all the growth is going as opposed to rack and that's where our strength clearly is.

In terms of the use case for it, we're getting a lot of use and, Rob, I'm going to ask about how service providers are going to do that and some of the things we do with hosted Unified Communication to you in a second. I'll take the enterprise piece.

The enterprise piece when you look and we've done our own surveys and we've looked at some outside surveys, we're getting the vast majority of the true production clouds in the enterprise space built off of Cisco and our partners. And our win rate there is extremely, extremely good. Service providers it's even better because very often they consider quote, "the incumbents" in the data center actually competitors.
And, Rob, a little bit about both where we're doing from a positioning perspective and a little bit how they're using it more than just in the Service Provider space.

So I think across our portfolio, John, the number one use case is private cloud. We're seeing, obviously, the move towards converged infrastructure playing very well to our strengths with UCS and the partners we have. The trend is our enterprise customers are looking for more benefits from automation and actually taking the benefits of virtualization even further.

The second most popular use case is for cloud providers where they are looking at provisioning and management as the number one area of focus. One of our use cases that's extremely strong is our own call control call manager offering as a hosted collaboration solution where we have dozens of service providers delivering call control as an enterprise class application from those centralized data centers.

The third use case is massively scalable data centers, which we're winning in and you've mentioned that before about our position there and the strength we've seen and some of the innovations we're bringing in those areas.

And then obviously, there are multiple use cases that exist across the board. But those are the three that we're focused on. We're winning in enterprise class apps. We are seeing Microsoft and SharePoint and other applications. We are seeing SAP and Oracle in their virtualized environments and actually I think our strength is that we are bringing this infrastructure to enterprise class applications and matching service providers, trying to drive services for business apps.

It's interesting, I'm going to talk about this at the sales meeting, Rob, a little bit more. But we had two really good competitors, medium sized, that recently have said the same thing from their top sales leadership to their field and that is that as Cisco sells technology and you compete against Cisco in technology you've got a chance. The minute this goes to the business decision makers and they begin to look at a business impact cost of ownership where they're trying to achieve their business goals, they are now telling these teams – one of them was a major wireless player and one of them was a major switch player in the data center – they're just saying you need to go away, you're not going to beat Cisco there. And it does speak to how our strategy is coming all together. It isn't about standalone products, it's about how do you solve customer problems. Not just in theory, but having the services behind it, Gary which your team is doing amazing on; having the capability to think about how you solve their problems with the British government.

I mean we did everything from job creation, to education, to helping in East London in terms of the implication to pulling off the Olympics to be an example of how you do innovation within a country and tie together the innovation centers. That's a different conversation than any company in the world has with a government leader and it's our ability to really pull that together and to teach ourselves which, Rob which I know is very key, they've not got to just learn products they've got to learn product technology architectures and then they can learn how to install their business architecture. But Brian would be the first one to lift up our enterprise environment to say that he's starting to see our ability to sell that, be more and more across the client directors in the business levels, Gary our ability to pull together services.

And I guess that's the right one to wrap up on, Mel. Bottom line for the quarter and for the year, we did what we said we would do, very pleased with the results. We appreciate you all's confidence and trust in us and continue to push us on the challenges. Our strategy and vision appears to be working well. We wouldn't have done the dividend commitment and the cash commitment if we didn't see stabilization in our business and have good confidence going forward. And most of the major market transitions we're all over and a couple of them where we've got good people we can do even better and I think you all brought it up in a couple of your questions and that's what you saw reflected in our guidance, probably more aggressive than most any of peers in the industry. We'll see if that's the right scenario or not and thank you for your confidence.
Mel, let me turn it back over to you.
Great. Thanks, John.

Please call the Investor Relations department with any follow-up questions from this call.
Thank you for your participation and continued support. This concludes our call.
